intro: Acer texanum, commonly known as the Texas maple, is a deciduous tree native to the southern United States. It typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has a broad, rounded crown. The leaves are palmately lobed, with a serrated margin, and turn vibrant shades of red and yellow in the fall. Its bark is smooth and grayish-brown, becoming fissured with age. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers in early spring, followed by winged samaras as its fruit.
